blocks.name: cgcd
blocks.content: Extend the definition of a class to include the greatest common divisor operator.
blocks.origin: const class cgcd { gcd }

df-gcd
blocks.content: Define the ` gcd ` operator. For example, ` ( -u 6 gcd 9 ) = 3 ` ( ~ ex-gcd ). For an alternate definition, based on the definition in [ApostolNT] p. 15, see ~ dfgcd2 . (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 21-Mar-2011.)

blocks.name: gcdval
blocks.content: The value of the ` gcd ` operator. ` ( M gcd N ) ` is the greatest common divisor of ` M ` and ` N ` . If ` M ` and ` N ` are both ` 0 ` , the result is defined conventionally as ` 0 ` . (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 21-Mar-2011.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 10-Nov-2013.)

} = {
  ovmpt2(hs0, hs1, c0, cz, c1, cz, cgcd, if((c0 = 0 ∧ c1 = 0), 0, sup({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]c1)}, ℝ, <)), if((hs0 = 0 ∧ hs1 = 0), 0, sup({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]hs0 ∧ s0[||]hs1)}, ℝ, <)), if((c0 = 0 ∧ hs1 = 0), 0, sup({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]hs1)}, ℝ, <)))

  supeq1d({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]hs0 ∧ s0[||]hs1)}, cr, clt, { s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]hs1)}, hs0 = c0)
  rabbidv(s0, cz, hs0 = c0, (s0[||]hs0 ∧ s0[||]hs1), (s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]hs1))
  anbi1d(hs0 = c0, s0[||]hs0, s0[||]hs1, s0[||]c0)

  ifbieq2d(nat0, sup({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]hs1)}, ℝ, <), sup({ s0 ∈ ℤ |(s0[||]c0 ∧ s0[||]c1)}, ℝ, <), hs1 = c1, (c0 = 0 ∧ hs1 = 0), (c0 = 0 ∧ c1 = 0))

blocks.name: gcd0val
blocks.content: The value, by convention, of the ` gcd ` operator when both operands are 0. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 21-Mar-2011.)

blocks.name: gcdn0val
blocks.content: The value of the ` gcd ` operator when at least one operand is nonzero. (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 21-Mar-2011.)

blocks.name: 6gcd4e2
blocks.content: The greatest common divisor of six and four is two. To calculate this gcd, a simple form of Euclid's algorithm is used: ` ( 6 gcd 4 ) = ( ( 4 + 2 ) gcd 4 ) = ( 2 gcd 4 ) ` and ` ( 2 gcd 4 ) = ( 2 gcd ( 2 + 2 ) ) = ( 2 gcd 2 ) = 2 ` . (Contributed by AV, 27-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:
